comments.author: Silly-Swimmer1706
comments.body: It's not against the law, it's just that people opt for long term contract or airbnb/booking. You could try offering to pay a bit more, or just plain and simple lie about it and be careful about details in contract regarding termination.

comments.author: TradicionalniAteist
comments.body:
Where are you going to study?

On my university, we had an international office that was dealing with many thing related to the exchange students snd one of those was helping with the accomodation.

It was good because if someone doesnt want to rent for just 6 months, this way they rent you for one semester and another student for another semester. Or something like that.

comments.author: SinkResponsible2021
comments.body: Yes, it's possible. We do have a new tax law about renting, so we have LTR (they have to be at least 10 months long) and STR through AirBnb, booking and similar platforms. You can try to book through platforms for, idk, week or two, and try to come with your landlord to an agreement for a few months to avoid high platform provisions. Good luck!
